Photography, which is typically a weak point on phones in this price range, is similarly mixed with decent photography in outdoor environments while struggling to photograph lowlight spaces. <a target=\\"_blank\\" rel=\\"\\" data-id=\\"5ee77d9b-ebc9-4ec1-a09d-abb850378185\\" href=\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-a15-5g-review-this-cheap-phone-is-a-stalwart\u002F\\">Read our full Samsung Galaxy A15 5G review<\u002Fa>.<\u002Fp><h3>Why we like it<\u002Fh3><p>The Samsung Galaxy A15 5G is a stalwart, functional choice when all you want is a stable phone. The A15's photo processing is decent for a phone in this price range. The photos I took outdoors look vivid, with enough detail that I'd be happy to post them on social networks. In a good way, the battery drains slowly and recharges fairly quickly thanks to its 25-watt wired charging.<\u002Fp><h3>Who's it best for<\u002Fh3><p>If you're looking for a low-cost phone that will be easy and safe to use for years, the A15 is an easy choice.<\u002Fp><h3>Who shouldn’t get it<\u002Fh3><p>If you don't mind possibly needing a new phone in two or three years, the $200 Moto G 5G and the $160 TCL 50 XL have better-looking displays that look smoother at their 120Hz refresh rates<\u002Fp><p><\u002Fp>","version":"<p><strong>Editor's Note:<\u002Fstrong> Samsung has also released the <a target=\\"_blank\\" rel=\\"\\" data-id=\\"0130a92d-1a0d-42ce-ad73-41e990f6a900\\" href=\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-a16-comes-to-us-at-200-with-6-years-of-updates\u002F\\">Galaxy A16<\u002Fa>.<\u002Fp><p>Samsung’s $200 Galaxy A15 5G is an easy choice for someone looking to buy a phone that will last for years. Samsung provides it with four years of software updates and five years of security support, which in this price range is unparalleled. Plus the phone supports 25W wired charging that in my testing was able to charge half of its big 5,000-mAh battery from empty in 30 minutes. I also like the eye-catching light blue option.<\u002Fp><p>A $200 phone has to have some compromises. The Galaxy A15 5G feels sluggish compared to competing phones like Motorola’s $200 Moto G 5G, and as an entertainment machine falls short with its single audio speaker that is blocked by accident when you hold the phone sideways for games and video. Photography, which is typically a weak point on phones in this price range, is similarly mixed with decent photography in outdoor environments while struggling to photograph lowlight spaces. This makes the Galaxy A15 5G an easy choice for when you just need a phone that can handle the basics, but you may want to consider other options if you are looking for the best pocket YouTube player in this price range.<\u002Fp>"}},"metadata":{"dateUpdated":{"date":"2025-06-22 10:30:03.753102","timezone_type":3,"timezone":"UTC"},"edition":"us","isPublished":true,"lastUpdatedBy":null,"newParentVersionId":"10e01396-e09f-4d2b-93b2-91cf8a677a4a","parentContentType":"content_article","parentId":"8b0ca799-9395-4787-aa6f-9ffb32b82f60","slug":"best-samsung-galaxy-phone","timestamp":1750588203000,"override":{"subhed":"Best ultracheap phone","description":"<p><strong>Editor's Note:<\u002Fstrong> Samsung has also released the <a target=\\"_blank\\" rel=\\"\\" data-id=\\"0130a92d-1a0d-42ce-ad73-41e990f6a900\\" href=\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-a16-comes-to-us-at-200-with-6-years-of-updates\u002F\\">Galaxy A16<\u002Fa>.<\u002Fp><p>Samsung’s $200 Galaxy A15 5G is an easy choice for someone looking to buy a phone that will last for years. \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Cshortcode shortcode=\"cross_content_listicle\" content=\"X - LIST ITEM\" id=\"6ec547b6-d5e6-4fdc-8192-efcfba38a844\" hed=\"Samsung Galaxy S25 Plus\" superlative=\"Best S25 Ultra alternative\" description=\"\u003Cp\u003EIf the baseline Galaxy S25 appeals to you but you'd rather have a bigger screen and higher battery capacity – without upgrading all the way to the Ultra – the S25 Plus may be the phone for you. The entire S25 lineup shares many features, from AI capabilities to processing power to memory, so the Plus may be a viable choice if you're looking for something right in the middle.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThat said, the Plus' minimal upgrades over the baseline S25 may not justify the $200 price difference. But if a bigger phone just feels better to hold and you'd rather have a 4,900 mAh battery (over the S25's 4,000mAh one), then that $1,000 starting price might ultimately be worth every penny. \u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="d2384c61-80e3-42a4-94d2-15e0771c3dee" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s25-and-s25-plus-review-ai-thats-enjoyable-without-being-overwhelming\u002F"\u003ERead CNET's full Samsung Galaxy S25 Plus review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile the baseline S25 checks all the key boxes, the S25 Plus can simply feel like a more comfortable device to use, especially if you're a fellow member of the bigger hands club. In addition to sharing many of the same features as the pricier S25 Ultra, the S25 Plus has a higher battery capacity than the baseline model -- though in CNET's tests, there weren't any major discrepancies in how the two batteries actually performed. Still, sometimes you just want to live a little larger, and this phone can be the perfect fit.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you like having a larger screen to watch movies or play games on, the S25 Plus can be a great choice. While the S25 Ultra might be a top pick for someone who wants both a bigger phone and the most premium features, the S25 Plus can be that goldilocks device that meets you right in the middle -- without you having to spend $1,300 on the Ultra.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you want the absolute best in terms of cameras, don't get the S25 Plus. For $1,000 phones like the Pixel 9 Pro or iPhone 16 Pro have better cameras. Or if you can afford to buy a $1,300 phone, check out the Galaxy S25 Ultra which has an amazing set of lenses\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\" page-position=\"\" tooltip-label=\"\" for productivity\" description=\"\u003Cp\u003EWith the \u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="f5a68926-6bf3-4781-9141-41d2e0d54bb6" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-z-fold-6-review-steps-forward-and-backward\u002F"\u003EGalaxy Z Fold 6\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Samsung is getting closer to its goal of making a device that doubles as a phone and a tablet without compromising too much in either direction. The Galaxy Z Fold 6 has an improved design with a sleeker look that’s easier to grip, a less noticeable crease, a new processor and an upgraded ultrawide camera.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBut it’s really the Galaxy Z Fold 6’s big, bright and crisp internal screen that makes it the best choice for those who want a foldable phone for entertainment. However, be prepared to spend a pretty penny: The Galaxy Z Fold 6 starts at an eye-watering $1,900, making it $100 more expensive than last year’s Z Fold 5 was at launch. Read our \u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="f5a68926-6bf3-4781-9141-41d2e0d54bb6" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-z-fold-6-review-steps-forward-and-backward\u002F"\u003ESasmung Galaxy Z Fold 6 in-depth review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWith the Galaxy Z Fold 6, Samsung finally achieved its goal of making a foldable that can truly replicate the experience of a traditional phone while doubling as a sleek tablet. Roughly five years after the original Galaxy Fold's launch, Samsung's book-shaped device has gotten lighter, slimmer, more durable and natural to use as a phone; a seemingly mundane but necessary improvement.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you can get past the sticker shock, there's a lot to love about the Galaxy Z Fold 6. I just don't know how many people are willing to fork over $1,900 to experience it. Carriers and retailers still offer some discounts that knock down that high price, but those deals usually come with conditions like trading in an eligible device or opening a new line of service.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESamsung also hasn't provided the two biggest things I'm looking for in tablet-style foldable phones: more affordable prices and innovative software that makes better use of their dual screens.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\" page-position=\"\" Thankfully, it doesn't scale back too much in the way of features and capabilities; it's got a powerful Snapdragon 8 Elite processor and the same 200-megapixel main camera you'll find on the top-of-the-line S25 Ultra (though there's no telephoto lens).&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe main sacrifice is battery life, as the S25 Edge has a 3,900-mAh battery, the lowest amount across the S25 series. It also only supports 25-watt wired charging. But it still offers enough juice to get you through the day, even if you're a notoriously heavy phone user. Plus, using something so remarkably feather-light feels like such a breath of fresh air, you may not mind making some compromises.&nbsp;\u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="f99c5f37-1951-42eb-b7b7-bd7802565f1e" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fi-was-wrong-about-the-galaxy-s25-edge-the-thin-phone-hype-might-be-legit\u002F"\u003ERead our full Galaxy S25 Edge review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe S25 Edge is surprisingly enjoyable to use and hold, given its lightweight design (it weighs 163 grams) and generous 6.7-inch screen. And despite its thinner frame, it feels surprisingly sturdy, thanks to its Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 display and Victus 2 backing. That means it doesn't feel like it's going to snap in your pocket -- and you'll hardly even feel it in there.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you want a phone that feels light and can slip easily into your pocket, without compromising too much on functionality, the S25 Edge is a great option. Plus, if you're looking for a fresh form factor but aren't interested in venturing into foldables territory, this unique phone is a solid -- and more familiar-feeling -- choice.&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EWho shouldn't get it \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you're looking for something more budget-friendly, the S25 Edge might not appeal to you. Also, if battery life is your top priority, the S25 Edge leaves something to be desired, since it only lasts about 24 hours before needing a recharge.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\" page-position=\"\" offering -- one that doesn't necessarily cater to most people's top priorities like longer battery life and an affordable price tag, and yet it still presents an alluring option with its slim frame and lightweight body. Thankfully, it doesn't scale back too much in the way of features and capabilities; it's got a powerful Snapdragon 8 Elite processor and the same 200-megapixel main camera you'll find on the top-of-the-line S25 Ultra (though there's no telephoto lens).&nbsp;<\u002Fp><p>The main sacrifice is battery life, as the S25 Edge has a 3,900-mAh battery, the lowest amount across the S25 series. It also only supports 25-watt wired charging. But it still offers enough juice to get you through the day, even if you're a notoriously heavy phone user. Plus, using something so remarkably feather-light feels like such a breath of fresh air, you may not mind making some compromises.&nbsp;<a target=\\"_blank\\" rel=\\"\\" data-id=\\"f99c5f37-1951-42eb-b7b7-bd7802565f1e\\" href=\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fi-was-wrong-about-the-galaxy-s25-edge-the-thin-phone-hype-might-be-legit\u002F\\">Read our full Galaxy S25 Edge review<\u002Fa>.<br><\u002Fp><p><strong>Why we like it<\u002Fstrong><\u002Fp><p>The S25 Edge is surprisingly enjoyable to use and hold, given its lightweight design (it weighs 163 grams) and generous 6.7-inch screen. And despite its thinner frame, it feels surprisingly sturdy, thanks to its Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 display and Victus 2 backing. That means it doesn't feel like it's going to snap in your pocket -- and you'll hardly even feel it in there.<br><\u002Fp><p><strong>Who it's best for <\u002Fstrong><\u002Fp><p>If you want a phone that feels light and can slip easily into your pocket, without compromising too much on functionality, the S25 Edge is a great option. Plus, if you're looking for a fresh form factor but aren't interested in venturing into foldables territory, this unique phone is a solid -- and more familiar-feeling -- choice.&nbsp;<\u002Fp><p><strong><br>Who shouldn't get it <\u002Fstrong><\u002Fp><p>If you're looking for something more budget-friendly, the S25 Edge might not appeal to you. The Galaxy S24 FE packs a good camera and costs only $650 before discounts or trade-in offers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETest your phone:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E It's worth going to a store and trying out a phone before you shell out hundreds of dollars for it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFind peace of mind with a case:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E You spent all this time picking a phone, now protect it from damage with a case.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBe ready for Cyber Monday sales:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E The holidays usually bring big discounts and sales, even on phones.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2 id=\"7df07299-e3d3-46a0-88de-10e6e77d8005\" data-ng-block=\"{"id":"yla9ffwok3kxhn0","type":"heading"}\"\u003E   How we test phones   \u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\u003Cshortcode shortcode=\"image\" uuid=\"c4ba5f71-ca44-44e4-a85a-abe8c3f23d3b\" size=\"large\" float=\"none\" lightbox=\"false\" image-do-not-resize=\"false\" image-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Fa\u002Fimg\u002Fresize\u002F609078e0f61a5d1cbfd203901fa8dc2fa47b0279\u002Fhub\u002F2025\u002F01\u002F21\u002Fc4ba5f71-ca44-44e4-a85a-abe8c3f23d3b\u002Fgalaxy-s25-ultra-1023612.jpg?auto=webp&height=500\" image-caption=\"\u003Cp\u003EWe test the battery, screen, performance, cameras and more on every phone we review.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\" image-credit=\"Lisa Eadiciccio\u002FCNET\" image-alt-text=\"Samsung Galaxy S23 Ultra\" image-filename=\"galaxy-s25-ultra-1023612.jpg\" image-target-url=\"\" image-credit-url=\"\" image-width=\"3701\" image-height=\"2082\" image-date-created=\"2025-01-21\" image-do-not-crop=\"true\" image-watermark=\"true\" ng-block=\"{"id":"pfw65556iowq7b1","type":"image"}\" edition=\"us\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWe test every phone in real-world scenarios focusing on its features, design, performance, cameras, battery life and overall value. We document our findings in an initial review that is periodically updated when there are new software updates or to compare against new phones from competitors like Apple, Samsung, Google and OnePlus.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch3 id=\"88a1ece3-d247-47df-80f2-aea090a8605d\" data-ng-block=\"{"id":"san5zt52w1ooxgo","type":"heading"}\"\u003EPhotography\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPhotography is a major focus for most phones these days, so we take pictures and videos of various subjects in a variety of settings and lighting levels. We try out any new camera modes such as 4K 120fps slow motion video that debuted with the iPhone 16 Pro and 16 Pro Max or AI reframe and focus on the Motorola Razr Plus (2024).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cshortcode shortcode=\"image\" uuid=\"08bd83ae-8018-49ed-988a-427a331737a3\" size=\"large\" float=\"none\" lightbox=\"false\" image-do-not-resize=\"false\" image-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Fa\u002Fimg\u002Fresize\u002F18199872a2beb537b529a249efb319ba7fbe25a1\u002Fhub\u002F2024\u002F07\u002F17\u002F08bd83ae-8018-49ed-988a-427a331737a3\u002Fimg-3157.jpg?auto=webp&height=500\" image-caption=\"\" image-credit=\"Lisa Eadiccico\u002FCNET\" image-alt-text=\"The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 6\" image-filename=\"img-3157.jpg\" image-target-url=\"\" image-credit-url=\"\" image-width=\"3000\" image-height=\"2250\" image-date-created=\"2024-07-17\" image-do-not-crop=\"true\" image-watermark=\"true\" ng-block=\"{"id":"9r6arzy5907j2ff","type":"image"}\" edition=\"us\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Ch3 id=\"16d57d9e-7d51-4b28-b386-8eea9fe46ce6\" data-ng-block=\"{"id":"7yu2cc9eyftd6g3","type":"heading"}\"\u003EBattery life\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBattery testing is conducted in a variety of ways. We assess how long a phone lasts during a typical day of use, and note how it performs during more focused sessions of video calls, media streaming and gaming. We also conduct a video playback test, which isn't always included in the initial review and is added later in an update.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch3 id=\"b7c52cd9-c68a-4799-9553-3e4d12ede810\" data-ng-block=\"{"id":"qqmq97wyvxh6q50","type":"heading"}\"\u003EPerformance\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWe perform processor-heavy tasks like editing photos, exporting videos and playing games. We evaluate whether a newer version of a particular phone includes enough features to make it worth upgrading from older models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cshortcode shortcode=\"image\" uuid=\"07521a29-5e5b-4abe-8411-6493e356ad07\" size=\"large\" float=\"none\" lightbox=\"false\" image-do-not-resize=\"false\" image-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Fa\u002Fimg\u002Fresize\u002Fae28fc293757d92c0956b7519fb7423ebe7d177b\u002Fhub\u002F2025\u002F04\u002F05\u002F07521a29-5e5b-4abe-8411-6493e356ad07\u002Fscreenshot-2025-04-05-at-1-21-27pm.jpg?auto=webp&height=500\" image-caption=\"\" image-credit=\"Jeffrey Hazelwood\u002FCNET\" image-alt-text=\"A chart showing the results of the 3DMark benchmark test\" image-filename=\"screenshot-2025-04-05-at-1-21-27pm.jpg\" image-target-url=\"\" image-credit-url=\"\" image-width=\"3000\" image-height=\"1688\" image-date-created=\"2025-04-05\" image-do-not-crop=\"true\" image-watermark=\"true\" ng-block=\"{"id":"7l1vevp7x9z4p5r","type":"image"}\" edition=\"us\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWe use benchmarking apps to measure the performance, alongside our own anecdotal experiences using the phone for our review. \u003C\u002Fshortcode\u003E is such a comfort to use that at moments our reviewer, Mike Sorrentino, felt like he was testing a scaled-back version of the $1,000 Galaxy S24 Plus. Many people prefer to stick with phones from the same company because the experience is more consistent and there's less of a learning curve when switching to a new device.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe same holds true for Samsung; the company's One UI software (its customized version of Android) can be found across its phone lineup. Samsung's One UI 6 introduced a more customizable lock screen and the ability to answer a phone call through a text message instead of speaking.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EConsistency aside, there are some benefits to choosing a Samsung phone over devices from other Android phone makers. Samsung usually excels when it comes to display quality and brightness, and it typically offers a lot of choices in terms of size and pricing. Samsung phones usually offer decent battery life -- especially midsize and large phones -- and the cameras are usually among the best, especially on the Galaxy S25 lineup. Samsung also offers seven years of Android version updates for most of its new smartphones, which is longer support than even Google provides for its Pixel phones.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="67d9ca32-5e93-4a76-9936-694a8ef9c15b" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fdont-drop-your-old-pixel-for-pixel-7-before-reading-our-comparison\u002F"\u003EGoogle's Pixel devices\u003C\u002Fa\u003E also have stellar cameras along with specific software features you can't get elsewhere. The Galaxy A lineup is Samsung's mid-tier and budget line, and it's the best choice if you're looking for a \u003Ca target="_blank" rel="" data-id="cc5903ef-5a5a-4019-83a9-5ec0ac2e66c0" href="https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fbest-phones-under-500\u002F"\u003Ephone under $500\u003C\u002Fa\u003E without a trade-in deal. These phones typically offer core features like a big screen, large battery and multiple cameras at a cheaper price.&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou also get what you pay for; Samsung's cheapest phones have very limited storage space and poorer cameras compared with the pricier models, and they sometimes struggle with juggling multiple tasks. More expensive phones like the Galaxy A35 5G provide almost everything most people want in a basic phone, although you'll still have to compromise a bit on camera quality and general performance.&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Galaxy S series, on the other hand, is Samsung's flagship smartphone line. Galaxy S phones usually include the best tech that Samsung has to offer and features you'd expect on any high-end phone, such as a premium design, 5G support, screens with high refresh rates and multiple high-end cameras. The biggest updates that launched with the Galaxy S25 lineup, for example, included the bump to a 200-megapixel main camera on the Ultra and bigger batteries for the smaller models. Luckily, Samsung gets a lot of other things right on the S25 Ultra, which has a new Snapdragon 8 Elite processor, high-resolution ultrawide camera, and some sweet pro video tools that rival the iPhone 16 Pro. Samsung wisely kept all the best parts of last year's Galaxy S24 Ultra (basically the entire phone including that antireflective display) but some of its worst parts, too, like the $1,300 price tag.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EIf you want the best screen you can find on any phone, get the S25 Ultra. If you want the most versatile phone cameras, get the S25 Ultra. If you want a stylus, get the S25 Ultra. But if your needs scale back on any of those fronts, the more affordable S25 options, or even last year's S24 Ultra, may be worth considering. \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"3df08996-e0bf-46f0-a3f0-f1895f30e08d\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s25-ultra-review-greatest-phone-screen-ever-and-lets-not-talk-about-the-ai\u002F\"\u003ERead our full Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe reason to get the Ultra over its S25 siblings is its screen, which is truly the best I've seen on any phone, and the cameras, which are a step above what the S25 and S25 Plus have. Added video features like ability to record in Log format gets the Ultra as close as it's ever been to the iPhone in terms of professional video capture.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you have a Galaxy S22 Ultra or older, the S25 Ultra will seem like a significant upgrade. It's harder to make that case for S23 Ultra owners, who, unless their phone's battery is ailing or they can score an incredible discount, should otherwise sit this one out. And for you S24 Ultra owners, you don't need this phone. Save your money and treat yourself to a nice steak dinner and a movie.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Galaxy S25 Ultra's appeal is muddied by its $1,300 price. The regular Galaxy S25 has the same functionality, power and longevity, and it costs $500 less. Want a bigger screen? Consider the Galaxy S25 Plus. It can take a rough sketch and turn it into artwork or help me have a conversation in French or Korean despite me only knowing a few words of either language. The new autofocus\u002Fauto zoom feature lets you prop the phone in a half-open position, the Z Flip 6 will automatically zoom in or out (switching between the main and ultrawide cameras) to get a photo that best suits the moment. But the AI features are the least impressive aspects of the the Z Flip 6.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESamsung's latest clamshell style foldable has a new 50-megapixel main camera, a smaller hinge and crease, a larger battery and a Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3. But all this comes at a higher starting price: $1,099 which makes it hard to appreciate the Galaxy Z Flip 6 for the absolute great phone that it is. \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"5e424539-6bee-48c8-9a2c-0566da763d31\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-z-flip-6-review-the-aha-moment-that-sold-me-until-i-saw-the-price\u002F\"\u003ERead our full review for the Samsung's Galaxy Z Flip 6\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESamsung's latest clamshell style foldable has a new 50-megapixel main camera, finally putting it on par with non-folding flagship phone cameras. The hinge is smaller and helps reduce the size of the crease on the internal screen. It has a new chip, the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3, and 12GB of RAM for flagship performance. There's even a larger battery. For all intents and purposes, the new Z Flip 6 is a Galaxy S24 that can fold in half – which is fantastic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you already have a Samsung phone and have been itching to try a flip phone, then then the Galaxy Z Flip 6 brings the software and features you're used to in a cutting-edge design that is equally nostalgic and seemingly futuristic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you spend a ton of time around dirt or sand, this phone isn't for href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s25-ultra-review-greatest-phone-screen-ever-and-lets-not-talk-about-the-ai\u002F\"\u003ES25 Ultra\u003C\u002Fa\u003E – but it does so for several hundred dollars less. You'll find features like the AI Select tool, Audio Eraser and deeper Gemini integration across \u003Cem\u003Eall \u003C\u002Fem\u003Eof Samsung's S25 devices, as well as a custom \u003Ca rel=\"\" data-id=\"4cafbc3f-2080-4815-a450-6d5611431904\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fqualcomms-snapdragon-8-elite-chip-aims-to-level-up-ai-on-android-phones\u002F\"\u003ESnapdragon 8 Elite\u003C\u002Fa\u003E processor and 12GB RAM – making the smaller phone of the bunch still seem pretty mighty. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EAnd while the Galaxy S25 might look incredibly similar to the \u003Ca rel=\"\" data-id=\"4cafbc3f-2080-4815-a450-6d5611431904\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s24-and-s24-plus-review-samsung-thank-you-for-prioritizing-battery-life\u002F\"\u003ES24\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and share many of the same specs, consistency isn't so bad when it means there's a consistently good camera and great battery life. \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"e787c610-72fb-44d9-9bb2-3d7fa4b6916d\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s25-and-s25-plus-review-ai-thats-enjoyable-without-being-overwhelming\u002F\"\u003ERead our full Samsung Galaxy S25 review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHaving a baseline phone, like the Galaxy S25, that delivers many of the same perks as more expensive models, is a huge plus in my book. And given the remarkable processing power, standout camera and seamless AI integration in the Galaxy S25 lineup, it's great that I can get all those premium features for $800.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you're someone who insists on buying a flagship device, the Galaxy S25 won't let you down. but if you have a device that's two years old or more, you might be enticed to tap into all the latest Galaxy AI and integrated Gemini features. Now, $800 isn't pocket change, and there are definitely \u003Ca rel=\"\" data-id=\"e53721be-7bce-43ea-bf52-c7d3cc643174\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fbest-cheap-phone\u002F\"\u003Eother options\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for those who want to be more budget conscious, but if you're willing to spend a bit more, the baseline S25 can be a great all-around choice.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou A16\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESamsung’s $200 Galaxy A15 5G is an easy choice for someone looking to buy a phone that will last for years. Samsung provides it with four years of software updates and five years of security support, which in this price range is unparalleled. Plus the phone supports 25W wired charging that in my testing was able to charge half of its big 5,000-mAh battery from empty in 30 minutes. I also like the eye-catching light blue option.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA $200 phone has to have some compromises. The Galaxy A15 5G feels sluggish compared to competing phones like Motorola’s $200 Moto G 5G, and as an entertainment machine falls short with its single audio speaker that is blocked by accident when you hold the phone sideways for games and video. Photography, which is typically a weak point on phones in this price range, is similarly mixed with decent photography in outdoor environments while struggling to photograph lowlight spaces. This makes the Galaxy A15 5G an easy choice for when you just need a phone that can handle the basics, but you may want to consider other options if you are looking for the best pocket YouTube player – without upgrading all the way to the Ultra – the S25 Plus may be the phone for you. The entire S25 lineup shares many features, from AI capabilities to processing power to memory, so the Plus may be a viable choice if you're looking for something right in the middle.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThat said, the Plus' minimal upgrades over the baseline S25 may not justify the $200 price difference. But if a bigger phone just feels better to hold and you'd rather have a 4,900 mAh battery (over the S25's 4,000mAh one), then that $1,000 starting price might ultimately be worth every penny. \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"d2384c61-80e3-42a4-94d2-15e0771c3dee\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fgalaxy-s25-and-s25-plus-review-ai-thats-enjoyable-without-being-overwhelming\u002F\"\u003ERead CNET's full Samsung Galaxy S25 Plus review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile the baseline S25 checks all the key boxes, the S25 Plus can simply feel like a more comfortable device to use, especially if you're a fellow member of the bigger hands club. In addition to sharing many of the same features as the pricier S25 Ultra, the S25 Plus has a higher battery capacity than the baseline model -- though in CNET's tests, there weren't any major discrepancies in how the two batteries actually performed. Still, sometimes you just want to live a little larger, and this phone can be the perfect fit.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you like having a larger screen to watch movies or play games on, the S25 Plus can be a great choice. While the S25 Ultra might be a top pick for someone who wants both a bigger phone and the most premium features, the S25 Plus can be that goldilocks device that meets you right in the middle -- without you having to spend $1,300 on the Ultra.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho shouldn’t get it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you want the absolute best in terms of cameras, don't get the S25 Plus. For $1,000 phones like the Pixel 9 Pro or iPhone 16 Pro have better cameras. its goal of making a device that doubles as a phone and a tablet without compromising too much in either direction. The Galaxy Z Fold 6 has an improved design with a sleeker look that’s easier to grip, a less noticeable crease, a new processor and an upgraded ultrawide camera.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBut it’s really the Galaxy Z Fold 6’s big, bright and crisp internal screen that makes it the best choice for those who want a foldable phone for entertainment. Read our \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"f5a68926-6bf3-4781-9141-41d2e0d54bb6\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fsamsung-galaxy-z-fold-6-review-steps-forward-and-backward\u002F\"\u003ESasmung Galaxy Z Fold 6 in-depth review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWith the Galaxy Z Fold 6, Samsung finally achieved its goal of making a foldable that can truly replicate the experience of a traditional phone while doubling as a sleek tablet. Roughly five years after the original Galaxy Fold's launch, Samsung's book-shaped device has gotten lighter, slimmer, more durable and natural to use as a phone; a seemingly mundane but necessary improvement.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you can get past the sticker shock, there's a lot to love about the Galaxy Z Fold 6. I just don't know how many people are willing to fork over $1,900 to experience it. doesn't necessarily cater to most people's top priorities like longer battery life and an affordable price tag, and yet it still presents an alluring option with its slim frame and lightweight body. Thankfully, it doesn't scale back too much in the way of features and capabilities; it's got a powerful Snapdragon 8 Elite processor and the same 200-megapixel main camera you'll find on the top-of-the-line S25 Ultra (though there's no telephoto lens). \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe main sacrifice is battery life, as the S25 Edge has a 3,900-mAh battery, the lowest amount across the S25 series. It also only supports 25-watt wired charging. But it still offers enough juice to get you through the day, even if you're a notoriously heavy phone user. Plus, using something so remarkably feather-light feels like such a breath of fresh air, you may not mind making some compromises. \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"f99c5f37-1951-42eb-b7b7-bd7802565f1e\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fi-was-wrong-about-the-galaxy-s25-edge-the-thin-phone-hype-might-be-legit\u002F\"\u003ERead our full Galaxy S25 Edge review\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy we like it\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe S25 Edge is surprisingly enjoyable to use and hold, given its lightweight design (it weighs 163 grams) and generous 6.7-inch screen. And despite its thinner frame, it feels surprisingly sturdy, thanks to its Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 display and Victus 2 backing. That means it doesn't feel like it's going to snap in your pocket -- and you'll hardly even feel it in there.\u003Cbr\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho it's best for \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you want a phone that feels light and can slip easily into your pocket, without compromising too much on functionality, the S25 Edge is a great option. Plus, if you're looking for a fresh form factor but aren't interested in venturing into foldables territory, this unique phone is a solid -- and more familiar-feeling -- choice. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EWho shouldn't get it \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you're looking for something more budget-friendly, the S25 Edge might not appeal to you. Also, if battery life is your top priority, the S25 Edge leaves something to be desired, since it only lasts about 24 hours before needing a recharge.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E",edition:c,hed:"Samsung Galaxy right phone for you depends on a variety of factors, such as your budget, your current phone and whether you own other mobile accessories from the same company, such as earbuds or smartwatches. Many people prefer to stick with phones from the same company because the experience is more consistent and there's less of a learning curve when switching to a new device.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe same holds true for Samsung; the company's One UI software (its customized version of Android) can be found across its phone lineup. Samsung's One UI 6 introduced a more customizable lock screen and the ability to answer a phone call through a text message instead of speaking.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EConsistency aside, there are some benefits to choosing a Samsung phone over devices from other Android phone makers. Samsung usually excels when it comes to display quality and brightness, and it typically offers a lot of choices in terms of size and pricing. Samsung phones usually offer decent battery life -- especially midsize and large phones -- and the cameras are usually among the best, especially on the Galaxy S25 lineup. Samsung also offers seven years of Android version updates for most of its new smartphones, which is longer support than even Google provides for its Pixel phones.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"67d9ca32-5e93-4a76-9936-694a8ef9c15b\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Fdont-drop-your-old-pixel-for-pixel-7-before-reading-our-comparison\u002F\"\u003EGoogle's Pixel devices\u003C\u002Fa\u003E also have stellar cameras along with specific software features you can't get elsewhere. The \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"\" data-id=\"67d9ca32-5e93-4a76-9936-694a8ef9c15b\" href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnet.com\u002Ftech\u002Fmobile\u002Foneplus-12-review-a-powerhouse-flagship-with-one-key-flaw\u002F\"\u003EOnePlus 13\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is also cheaper than the Galaxy S24 Plus and Galaxy S24 Ultra at regular prices without a trade-in and offers faster charging speeds. These phones typically offer core features like a big screen, large battery and multiple cameras at a cheaper price. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou also get what you pay for; Samsung's cheapest phones have very limited storage space and poorer cameras compared with the pricier models, and they sometimes struggle with juggling multiple tasks. More expensive phones like the Galaxy A35 5G provide almost everything most people want in a basic phone, although you'll still have to compromise a bit on camera quality and general performance. \u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Galaxy S series, on the other hand, is Samsung's flagship smartphone line. Galaxy S phones usually include the best tech that Samsung has to offer and features you'd expect on any high-end phone, such as a premium design, 5G support, screens with high refresh rates and multiple high-end cameras. The biggest updates that launched with the Galaxy S25 lineup, for example, included the bump to a 200-megapixel main camera on the Ultra and bigger batteries for the smaller models.
